stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the boss fight against 'Block'. Key activities included implementing the boss's fleeing and damage-taking behaviors, a deep-dive into graphics combiners for a flashing damage effect, and a major thematic and geometric redesign of the boss arena from an 'oil barrel' to a 'warehouse in a cave'. The stream also highlighted a critical issue with the game's ROM size approaching the 64MB limit due to music.

development_findings.summary: The project is facing a critical ROM space issue, with 35.6MB of the 45.9MB file size being uncompressed, streamed music. This is forcing the team to consider converting some tracks to lower-quality sequenced music to stay within the 64MB limit.
development_findings.quote: Two-thirds of the ROM is just music that we cannot compress.

development_findings.summary: Kaze dismisses the idea of rewriting the project in C++ for better readability, arguing that code comprehension is a matter of programmer skill, not language choice.
development_findings.quote: I don't think C++ was how well the... yeah sure I can do that right perfect... I feel like that's just a skill issue if someone can't read your code.

development_findings.summary: Kaze prioritizes performance and memory efficiency by reusing existing, unused variables in the object struct rather than creating new ones, avoiding the performance cost of expanding the struct for every object in the game.
development_findings.quote: I'm looking for unused ones that I can just reuse. So I don't need to make new ones... Because that would expand the object struct and we would lose four bytes for every object in the entire world.

development_findings.summary: The boss arena's theme was changed mid-stream from a 'giant oil barrel' to a 'warehouse built into a cave' to better fit the narrative and provide a more visually interesting environment.
development_findings.quote: I think we just need a different theming for the area somehow... I think a warehouse would be perfect here, because you can chain people to a warehouse and it would make sense.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is against using button prompts to teach mechanics, preferring to design encounters that are intuitive for the player to figure out on their own.
development_findings.quote: I also think button prompts are kind of just like an ugly way to solve issues like this.

development_findings.summary: Kaze solved a major lighting issue in the boss arena by realizing he had confused the coordinate system, mistakenly setting Z as the 'up' axis instead of Y, which is standard for Mario 64.
development_findings.quote: Oh my god, I have Unreal Engine problems. Look, I changed to Z-Normal because I thought Z was up, but it's obviously Y. Why did no one tell me?

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided against a mechanic where the boss would slowly get bigger (heal) if the player took too long, in order to keep the difficulty from becoming too punishing and widening the skill gap.
development_findings.quote: I don't want the gap between like a bad player and a good player to be too big.

development_findings.summary: The central mechanic for damaging the boss involves receiving soap bars from a friendly janitor Koopa, who is helping the player because he was the only worker not on strike.
development_findings.quote: The idea here is that the strike workers are all in here and they like want to help you... the janitor Cooper that we have in the main world... he's just there with his bucket and throw soap at you.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes games should offer freedom and not gate content behind character swaps or repetitive, unengaging tasks, citing the 'Bully' and 'Yoshi's Island' remake as negative examples.
context_findings.quote: Video games are not supposed to be chores! That's my rant for the day.

context_findings.summary: Kaze distinguishes between personal preference and objective good, expressing a strong disdain for the philosopher Immanuel Kant, whom he blames for modern problems.
context_findings.quote: There's a difference between me saying I want something this way and me saying I think it'd be good if something was this way.

context_findings.summary: Kaze explains his tendency to take jokes seriously, believing they often contain a kernel of truth that warrants a serious response.
context_findings.quote: When you make a joke there's also like this little implication of an underlying truth to it, right? Not every joke is like purely fictional. And because of that underlying truth that a joke applies I feel like I have to respond to them seriously sometimes.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views the idea of swear words being inherently bad as a strange 'American concept' and would not enforce strict rules against swearing with his own children.
context_findings.quote: If I have a kid and the kid is four, the kid can't say fucking shit all at once. I don't think my parents will appreciate that. Well, fuck them.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reminds viewers that development is constrained by his full-time job and he cannot commit to a release date due to unpredictable life events.
context_findings.quote: I have a full-time job. I can't work on this unlimitedly and there might be any number of things coming in between this and the release date.

context_findings.summary: Kaze and his partner, Zeina, have bought a house and are moving soon. He anticipates his new workspace will be a 'dungeon' with no windows.
Kaze received a disturbing and aggressive message on Discord from a stranger who was angry about his opinion on philosophy.
Kaze states that with significantly more funding, his core passion would remain making games, but he would scale up his operation by hiring a larger team.
context_findings.quote: If I had mr. beast money I would just make games forever... I would hire more game more people to help me make games. We'd be the big company.

biobak.summary: Biobak engaged in a deep technical discussion with Kaze about graphics combiners, asking specific questions that led to Kaze providing a detailed mathematical explanation of how to blend colors for effects.
biobak.quote: My second question is, why can't I do text0, 0, 0, shadeColor to add instead of multiply? But it turns out you can, so I'm just... Oh. Well.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a reworked model for an object in the level, though Kaze noted the pivot point had been moved.
Biobak and Kaze had a minor creative disagreement about a tree stump texture; Kaze preferred his version, stating Biobak's choice 'looked terrible' on the model.
biobak.quote: Sorry, descriptive feedback, it just looked terrible on the stump. Like, try it. It doesn't look fitting.

badub.summary: Badub created a new song for the 'boombox koopas'.
Badub suggested a music optimization technique where a repeating background beat could be streamed separately from other instruments to save space.

zeina.summary: Zeina observes that Kaze's extensive experience as a developer has led to him having very high standards for what he considers a good game.
zeina.quote: With how long you've made games, with the amount of time you've spent making games, you have very high standards for what a good game should be, in your opinion.

zeina.summary: Zeina jokes about Kaze's work habits in their new house, implying he will be so focused in his windowless office that he'll need to be reminded to get sunlight.
zeina.quote: I might have to drag him upstairs to get some sun from time to time.

zeina.summary: Zeina participated in the discussion about the game 'Bully', sharing her perspective on its gameplay and design.

key_stories.title: Implementing the Boss Damage Flash
key_stories.summary: The initial damage animation was ineffective because it was only on the boss's face. After a technical discussion about graphics combiners, Kaze implemented a full-body orange flash effect that clearly communicates damage to the player from any angle.
key_stories.challenge: The team needed a clear and effective way to show the boss taking damage, but the effect had to be visible from the back, where the player will be most of the time.
key_stories.process: Kaze first considered a mouth animation but realized it wouldn't be visible. He then decided to use a primitive color flash. Prompted by Biobak's questions, he explained the complex math behind using graphics combiners to blend between the texture color and a primitive color. He implemented the effect, debugged a reset issue, and changed the color from blue to a more visible orange.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze implemented a full-body flashing effect that smoothly transitions the boss's color to orange. This provides clear, continuous damage feedback regardless of the player's position.
key_stories.key_quote: I have one issue with this damage animation and that is that it's only around his mouth and you're gonna mostly be seeing him from the back when this happens.

key_stories.title: Boss Arena Thematic Redesign
key_stories.summary: Kaze and the team were unhappy with the simplistic 'oil barrel' boss arena. Through collaborative brainstorming, they pivoted to a more complex and narratively-rich 'warehouse in a cave' concept, which Kaze began implementing during the stream.
key_stories.challenge: The initial 'giant oil barrel' theme for the boss arena felt visually uninspired, repetitive, and didn't align well with the game's narrative elements.
key_stories.process: Kaze expressed his dissatisfaction with the current barrel design. The team brainstormed alternatives, including a junkyard and oil tankers. They eventually settled on the warehouse/cave hybrid, as it made narrative sense for an 'oil warehouse' and allowed for the verticality and enclosed space Kaze wanted. Kaze immediately began blocking out the new geometry.
key_stories.outcome: The team decided on a new theme: an industrial warehouse built into a cave, with a tilted, sinking platform. This concept was deemed more visually dynamic and provided a logical setting for jailed characters to be present.
key_stories.key_quote: I think we just need a different theming for the area somehow... Maybe giant oil barrel is not the right play at all.

key_stories.title: The 64MB ROM Size Crisis
key_stories.summary: The team discovered their ROM size is becoming critically large due to high-quality streamed music. They are now forced to strategize on how to compress or alter future music tracks to ensure the final game fits within the 64MB N64 cartridge limit.
key_stories.challenge: The project is rapidly approaching the 64MB ROM size limit for N64 cartridges, with high-quality streamed music being the primary cause, consuming nearly 70% of the total space.
key_stories.process: Kaze calculated their current trajectory and realized they were on track to exceed the 64MB limit. He identified streamed music as the main issue. The team discussed several options: converting some streamed tracks to sequenced music (risking lower quality and higher CPU usage), converting stereo tracks to mono, or using a hybrid approach suggested by Badub.
key_stories.outcome: The team is now acutely aware of the space limitations and must be more conservative with music choices for the remaining levels. They have identified potential solutions but have not yet implemented a definitive strategy.
key_stories.key_quote: Our ROM is 45.9 megabytes... two-thirds of the ROM is just music that we cannot compress.
